header.heading: Sam
header.subHeading: I reseach brains and how they change over time
header.text: I'm currently finishing a PhD in Computational Psychiatry & Neuroscience at University College London.

content: I am a cognitive neuroscientist based in London. We use advanced methods to deconstruct people's choices into the recipes they used to make them.
For example, why did you decide to keep reading?
Choices reveal how our brains work and are linked to our wellbeing. Through this work, we hope to better predict and treat common mental disorders.

My PhD is supervised by Prof Tobias Hauser (UCL/Tuebingen University) and Professor Oliver Robinson (UCL). I also receive mentorship from Prof Essi Viding (UCL) and Dr Patricia Lockwood (University of Oxford/University of Birmingham), and funding from the Medical Research Council and Wellcome Trust.
I started my research career as a Clinical Research Assistant at the University of Cambridge working with Professor Roger Barker.
I'm also a graduate of UCL's Brain & Mind Sciences MSc & the University of Bristol (Experimental Psychology).
I'm currently thinking about my next role, so please get in touch if you'd like to discuss this.

Projects.title: Dopamine and effort learning
Projects.description: how do we learn how rewarding and effortful things are?

highlights.heading: Learning is a key aspect of decision-making
details: We know from previous research that people prefer to avoid effort, unless the reward is sufficient to justify it. People differ in how rewarding and effortful they perceive and experience things, but also in how they learn this over time.
We are investigate the role of dopamine in learning about reward and effort in a randomised double-blind placebo controlled study using L-dopa in 60 healthy young adults.
This means we give participants a drug that increases dopamine levels in the brain, and then measure how this affects their learning about reward and effort.

highlights.heading: This work builds on a previous study (Hauser et al., 2017, PNAS)
details: This study showed that reward-effort learning signals occur in separable brain circuitry in dorsomedial prefrontal and ventral striatal areas.
Participants have to learn how effort and rewarding stimuli are through reinforcement (trial and error).

Projects.title: Fluctuations in motivation
Projects.description: How do day-to-day changes in how we feel predict our decision-making?

highlights.heading: Smartphone-based research to track motivation over time
details: We are using innovative methods to disentangle links between decision-making and mental health across people (on average) from within-people (over time).
This improves the ecological validity of computational psychiatry by contextualising decision-making within the ebb and flow of daily life.
We have found evidence that motivation fluctuates significantly over days and weeks, and that individuals differ substantially in how this unfolds.

highlights.heading: A mobile game to measure motivational state
details: I adapted a desktop task created by Dr Agnes Norbury and Prof Quentin Huys to create a brief, engaging mobile game to measure motivational state as people go out about their daily lives.

highlights.heading: A dashboard to capture EEG entropy statistics in real-time
details: In collaboration with Anthony Sterling (https://anthonysterling.com/) & Chris Davison, we developed a dashboard to compute & display in real-time the entropy of the human brain recorded using a mobile EEG device
The right image is a cropped example, and the gif you saw before is a visualisation of the source reconstruction of EEG activity in real-time using Lab Streaming Layer API & Neuropype.

highlights.heading: Abstract
details: Apathy is linked to mental health and altered neurocognitive functions such as learning and decision-making in healthy adults. Mental health problems typically begin to emerge during adolescence, yet little is known about how apathy develops due to an absence of quantitative measurements specific to young people. Here, we present and evaluate the Apathy Motivation Index–Child Version (AMI-CV) for children and adolescents. We show across two samples of young people (aged 8 to 17 years, total N = 191) tested in schools in the UK and on a smartphone app, that the AMI-CV is a short, psychometrically sound measure to assess levels of apathy and motivation in young people. Similar to adult versions, the AMI-CV captures three distinct apathy domains: Behavioural Activation, Social Motivation and Emotional Sensitivity. The AMI-CV showed excellent construct validity with an alternative measure of apathy and external validity replicating specific links with related mental health traits shown in adults. Our results provide a short measure of self-reported apathy in young people that enables research into apathy development. The AMI-CV can be used in conjunction with the adult version to investigate the impact of levels of apathy across the lifespan.

highlights.heading: Objectives
details: To assess the role of visual measures and retinal volume to predict the risk of Parkinson disease (PD) dementia.

highlights.heading: Methods
details: In this cohort study, we collected visual, cognitive, and motor data in people with PD. Participants underwent ophthalmic examination, retinal imaging using optical coherence tomography, and visual assessment including acuity and contrast sensitivity and high-level visuoperception measures of skew tolerance and biological motion. We assessed the risk of PD dementia using a recently described algorithm that combines age at onset, sex, depression, motor scores, and baseline cognition.

highlights.heading: Results
details: Results: One hundred forty-six people were included in the study (112 with PD and 34 age-matched controls). The mean disease duration was 4.1 (±2·5) years. None of these participants had dementia. Higher risk of dementia was associated with poorer performance in visual measures (acuity: ρ = 0.29, p = 0.0024; contrast sensitivity: ρ = −0.37, p < 0.0001; skew tolerance: ρ = −0.25, p = 0.0073; and biological motion: ρ = −0.26, p = 0.0054). In addition, higher risk of PD dementia was associated with thinner retinal structure in layers containing dopaminergic cells, measured as ganglion cell layer (GCL) and inner plexiform layer (IPL) thinning (ρ = −0.29, p = 0.0021; ρ = −0.33, p = 0.00044). These relationships were not seen for the retinal nerve fiber layer that does not contain dopaminergic cells and were not seen in unaffected controls.

highlights.heading: Conclusion
details: Conclusion: Visual measures and retinal structure in dopaminergic layers were related to risk of PD dementia. Our findings suggest that visual measures and retinal GCL and IPL volumes may be useful to predict the risk of dementia in PD.

highlights.heading: What is already known on this topic
details: Huntington’s disease (HD) gene carriers can underestimate their impairments when asked to explicitly reflect on them. However, self-reports about cognition and daily life are confounded by many factors.

highlights.heading: What this study adds
details: This study shows that insight into cognitive performance remains intact in high functioning, premanifest and early-manifest HD gene carriers, even when the cognitive performance itself is impaired.

highlights.heading: How this study might affect research, practice or policy
details: Insight into impaired cognition is a putative mechanism for increased anxiety and depression commonly reported by HD gene carriers, which should be further investigated. Psychological interventions which use metacognition may help some early HD gene carriers exploit this intact skill to benefit their quality of life.

Publications.title: Dopamine cell replacement for Parkinson’s disease

highlights.heading: Abstract
details: Clinical studies of Parkinson’s disease (PD) using a dopamine cell replacment strategy have been tried for more than 30 years. The outcomes following transplantation of human fetal ventral mesencephalic tissue (hfVM) have been variable, with some patients coming off their anti-PD treatment for many years and others not responding and/or developing significant side effects, including graft-induced dyskinesia. This led to a re-appraisal of the best way to do such trials, which resulted in a new European-Union-funded allograft trial with fetal dopamine cells across several centers in Europe. This new trial, TRANSEURO (NCT01898390), is an open-label study in which some individuals in a large observational cohort of patients with mild PD who were undergoing identical assessments were randomly selected to receive transplants of hfVM. The TRANSEURO trial is currently ongoing as researchers have completed both recruitment into a large multicenter observational study of younger onset early-stage PD and transplantation of hfVM in 11 patients. While completion of TRANSEURO is not expected until 2021, we feel that sharing the rationale for the design of TRANSEURO, along with the lessons we have learned along the way, can help inform researchers and facilitate planning of transplants of dopamine-producing cells derived from human pluripotent stem cells for future clinical trials.
